pros: Great people to work with
cons: Low salary but nice enviornment

pros: I can not think any.
cons: I recently had the unfortunate experience of being employed at Marywood University as a tenure-track assistant professor, and I must say that it was the worst employment situation I have ever encountered. After dedicating one and a half years of my life to this institution, my position was abruptly eliminated. This decision left me baffled and deeply disappointed in the university's management. When I approached the dean to understand the reasoning behind the elimination of my position, I was met with a feeble explanation. Apparently, the university was facing financial difficulties, and as a result, they were reducing the number of full-time faculty members. However, instead of offering support or exploring alternatives, the dean proposed that I continue working as an adjunct professor. This response demonstrated a complete lack of understanding and regard for the value of a tenure-track position. It is disheartening to witness how the management of Marywood University is actively contributing to the deterioration of their own institution. The decision to downsize the number of professors is not only short-sighted but also detrimental to the quality of education offered. Professors and students form the backbone of any university, and by compromising the number of professors, the university is directly compromising the quality of education and potentially hindering student enrollment. Furthermore, the lack of coordination between different departments at Marywood University is alarming. There should be a cohesive and uniform system in place, especially in crucial areas such as HR and IT. The absence of such a system not only creates confusion and inefficiency but also hinders the overall functioning of the institution. In conclusion, my experience at Marywood University has been extremely disappointing. The decision to eliminate my tenure-track position without exploring alternatives, coupled with the lack of coordination between departments, reflects a mismanagement that is detrimental to the university's future. I sincerely hope that the management realizes the importance of professors and students as the lifeblood of any educational institution and takes necessary steps to rectify these shortcomings.

review_title: It doesn't get better and it never will.
job_title: Former Middle Manager in Binghamton, NY
pros:
I'll say two nice things.

1. The people you work with are and have been the best part of Marywood. 
2. The PTO and paid holidays were always very generous.
cons:
If I had to chose one word to describe the environment at Marywood, it would be turbulent. 

The financial issues that have plagued the university for decades have only gotten worse. Massive cuts to programs, even tighter budgets, outsourcing of whole departments, and raise and hiring freezes are in place again. Low pay always seems to be part of an NPO, but it's always been even lower at Marywood. 

There was hope that things would get better when Sr. Persico became president, but she (and the board of trustees) seem to have continued the poor decisions of her predecessor. It seems like the management from the top down can't get their act together, aside from giving themselves new titles every few years. 

The worry about the forthcoming "enrollment cliff" is real and Marywood's plan for it is not anywhere near sufficient, in my opinion. I fear this will be the breaking point for the institution.

This Marywood is not the Marywood I came to work at over 15 years ago. I am saddened to see my alma mater in such distress, and I worry that it won't be around much longer if there isn't massive changes in leadership now.

pros: Good people, though it's a Catholic University and, though people are friendly and "tolerant," they are not as supportive of those who violate their values. The pay was fair, the community quiet. I was never pushed to do the impossible, though I was given as much as I could handle. Partial tuition support for part time was great.
cons: Just that they wouldn't put congrats for alumni that are homosexual in the alumni magazine. I'm not gay, but I want to celebrate milestones for fellow alumni no matter their orientation.

review_title: They are in serious financial trouble
pros: Some professors are truely committed, but they have been mostly forced into retirement. Like everywhere you go, most sudents want to learn and are great and hardworking.
cons: Serious, I mean serious, gossipping and backbiting among staff clear through the president. Extremely provencial. Due to a number of issues, financial mismanagement, changes in structure, etc. they are breaking all kinds of endowments in order to make ends meet. This college was created to give educational opportunities to the poor daughters of coal miners. Now it is an elitist institution.

pros: Some great new facilities: Library / "Learning Commons," School of Architecture, and Fine Arts building.
cons:
Experienced poor leadership and management at the department level. 

Individuals in leadership positions repeatedly disregard concerns brought forth by students and faculty regarding the  quality of instruction in some courses.  

Poor morale among the students and faculty routinely ignored by leadership.  

I have seen competent and knowledgeable instructors forced out by politically ambitious colleagues and superiors with little or no practical knowledge of the subject matter.

review_title: Great if you need free tuition
pros: 100% tuition paid for employees & their kids
cons: Most people just work for the free tuition and then quit once they finish school or their kids graduate. (Note that free tuition does not include the exhorbitant fees and book costs.) Pay is about 1/3 less than elsewhere. When I left, there was a lot of talk about staff reductions and people were being let go seemingly at random. Employees afraid to say anything -- even offer positive ideas -- because of the threat of job loss. Way to get ahead is to befriend someone in management so you are "protected." Management does not communicate with employees;  major changes often happen suddenly and staff is expected to adapt with little or no notice, training, or guidance. General atmosphere of fear and repression keeps university from truly growing or providing quality education.

pros: Pay is reasonable based on cost of living, generally nice employees and students, good benefits.  People try to be helpful in any way they can and genuinely care. Discount on meals in the dining hall (which is a good deal and there's a good variety). Free gym membership on campus.
cons: Long hours (little work-life balance), politics (then again, it is academia, so it's to be expected).  Communication issues between some people and sometimes it's difficult to know about protocol because it might not be stated.

- flexible hours
- ability to easily communicate with staff
- enjoyable coworkers
- fun atmosphere

cons: Inability to do "study" during "work study". Although I do understand the need to be present in times of work, typically during downtime on the job you are afforded the opportunity to study or do homework when appropriate. It was my experience with the athletic department that this was not the case, and outside work for school was not permitted

pros: It has become very difficult to name “pros.”
cons: When you think the level of administrative incompetence can not get worse, it does! There are revolving doors at the middle and upper administrative level.  At one time Marywood had a very strong faculty, but the good ones leave.  Experienced professors get replaced by adjuncts with little it no experience. The standards by which students are held goes down every year. These days the school will accept just anout anyone just to get their tuition money. I’m not sure how much longer this University will be able to compete in the real world.
